text: The law requires petty lords and landed knights to take their disputes to their liege lord, and abide by his judgment, while disputes between great houses were adjudicated by the Crown.

metadata.section_title: The law requires petty lords and landed knights to take their disputes to their liege lord, and abide by his judgment, while disputes between great houses were adjudicated by the Crown.
metadata.full_path: 1. Peace > 1.1. The law requires petty lords and landed knights to take their disputes to their liege lord, and abide by his judgment, while disputes between great houses were adjudicated by the Crown.

text: king Maegor raised a set of laws which forbade holy men from carrying arms

metadata.section_title: king Maegor raised a set of laws which forbade holy men from carrying arms
metadata.full_path: 2. Religion > 2.1. king Maegor raised a set of laws which forbade holy men from carrying arms

text: The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit.

metadata.section_title: The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit.
metadata.full_path: 3. Widows > 3.1. The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit.

text: However, the law requires the heirs to maintain their father's surviving widow, no matter whether she had been a second, third, or even later wife, under the same conditions as she had been before her husband’s death.

metadata.section_title: However, the law requires the heirs to maintain their father's surviving widow, no matter whether she had been a second, third, or even later wife, under the same conditions as she had been before her husband’s death.
metadata.full_path: 3. Widows > 3.1. The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit. > 3.1.1. However, the law requires the heirs to maintain their father's surviving widow, no matter whether she had been a second, third, or even later wife, under the same conditions as she had been before her husband’s death.

text: The widows could no longer be driven from their late husband’s castle, deprived of her servants or possessions, or her income.

metadata.section_title: The widows could no longer be driven from their late husband’s castle, deprived of her servants or possessions, or her income.
metadata.full_path: 3. Widows > 3.1. The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit. > 3.1.2. The widows could no longer be driven from their late husband’s castle, deprived of her servants or possessions, or her income.

text: The law similarly prevented men from disinheriting the children from an earlier marriage in favor of children from a later marriage

metadata.section_title: The law similarly prevented men from disinheriting the children from an earlier marriage in favor of children from a later marriage
metadata.full_path: 3. Widows > 3.1. The Widow's Law reaffirms the right of the eldest son (or eldest daughter, if there are no sons) to inherit. > 3.1.3. The law similarly prevented men from disinheriting the children from an earlier marriage in favor of children from a later marriage

text: Trials of the Crown

metadata.section_title: Trials of the Crown
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.1. Trials of the Crown

text: Trials, at least among the nobility, often begin with a prayer from a septon beseeching the Father Above to guide them towards justice. The accused and witnesses are sworn to honesty before he gives testimony at a trial. The accused is allowed to be present as witnesses give their testimony, in front of one or multiple judges.

metadata.section_title: Trials, at least among the nobility, often begin with a prayer from a septon beseeching the Father Above to guide them towards justice. The accused and witnesses are sworn to honesty before he gives testimony at a trial. The accused is allowed to be present as witnesses give their testimony, in front of one or multiple judges.
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.1. Trials of the Crown > 4.1.1. Trials, at least among the nobility, often begin with a prayer from a septon beseeching the Father Above to guide them towards justice. The accused and witnesses are sworn to honesty before he gives testimony at a trial. The accused is allowed to be present as witnesses give their testimony, in front of one or multiple judges.

text: Trials by combat

metadata.section_title: Trials by combat
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.2. Trials by combat

text: Any knight accused of wrongdoing is allowed by law to demand a trial by combat. The right to a trial by combat also extends to nobles who are not knighted.

metadata.section_title: Any knight accused of wrongdoing is allowed by law to demand a trial by combat. The right to a trial by combat also extends to nobles who are not knighted.
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.2. Trials by combat > 4.2.1. Any knight accused of wrongdoing is allowed by law to demand a trial by combat. The right to a trial by combat also extends to nobles who are not knighted.

text: The accused and accusers are allowed to have champions fight in their place. When a person is killed in a trial by combat, by law it is not considered murder.

metadata.section_title: The accused and accusers are allowed to have champions fight in their place. When a person is killed in a trial by combat, by law it is not considered murder.
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.2. Trials by combat > 4.2.2. The accused and accusers are allowed to have champions fight in their place. When a person is killed in a trial by combat, by law it is not considered murder.

text: A more ancient custom, though seldom used, is a trial of seven, in which seven men fight on the side of the accusing party, and seven on the side of the accused party

metadata.section_title: A more ancient custom, though seldom used, is a trial of seven, in which seven men fight on the side of the accusing party, and seven on the side of the accused party
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.2. Trials by combat > 4.2.3. A more ancient custom, though seldom used, is a trial of seven, in which seven men fight on the side of the accusing party, and seven on the side of the accused party

text: When the person who stands accused is royalty, their champion has to be a knight of the Kingsguard. When the accuser is royalty, however, they are within their rights to select a champion who is not a sworn member of the Kingsguard.

metadata.section_title: When the person who stands accused is royalty, their champion has to be a knight of the Kingsguard. When the accuser is royalty, however, they are within their rights to select a champion who is not a sworn member of the Kingsguard.
metadata.full_path: 4. Trials > 4.2. Trials by combat > 4.2.4. When the person who stands accused is royalty, their champion has to be a knight of the Kingsguard. When the accuser is royalty, however, they are within their rights to select a champion who is not a sworn member of the Kingsguard.

text: In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally.

metadata.section_title: In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally.
metadata.full_path: 5. Taxes > 5.1. In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally.

text: Lords pay taxes to the crown.

metadata.section_title: Lords pay taxes to the crown.
metadata.full_path: 5. Taxes > 5.1. In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally. > 5.1.1. Lords pay taxes to the crown.

text: The Great Houses gather the taxes from their region.

metadata.section_title: The Great Houses gather the taxes from their region.
metadata.full_path: 5. Taxes > 5.1. In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally. > 5.1.2. The Great Houses gather the taxes from their region.

text: The Great Houses subsequently pay their taxes to the Crown. An exception are taxes owed to the Night’s Watch by the villages and holdfasts located in the New Gift which are paid in kind, not in gold.

metadata.section_title: The Great Houses subsequently pay their taxes to the Crown. An exception are taxes owed to the Night’s Watch by the villages and holdfasts located in the New Gift which are paid in kind, not in gold.
metadata.full_path: 5. Taxes > 5.1. In the Seven Kingdoms, taxes are collected locally. > 5.1.2. The Great Houses gather the taxes from their region. > 5.1.2.1. The Great Houses subsequently pay their taxes to the Crown. An exception are taxes owed to the Night’s Watch by the villages and holdfasts located in the New Gift which are paid in kind, not in gold.

text: Lords can have treasurers in their service to handle the incoming taxes.

metadata.section_title: Lords can have treasurers in their service to handle the incoming taxes.
metadata.full_path: 5. Taxes > 5.2. Lords can have treasurers in their service to handle the incoming taxes.

text: It is customary for a thief to be punished by losing a finger or a hand.

metadata.section_title: It is customary for a thief to be punished by losing a finger or a hand.
metadata.full_path: 6. Thievery > 6.1. It is customary for a thief to be punished by losing a finger or a hand.

text: Pickpockets can likewise be punished by cutting off a hand.

metadata.section_title: Pickpockets can likewise be punished by cutting off a hand.
metadata.full_path: 6. Thievery > 6.2. Pickpockets can likewise be punished by cutting off a hand.

text: Those who steal from a sept can be considered to have stolen from the gods, and thus receive a harsher punishment.

metadata.section_title: Those who steal from a sept can be considered to have stolen from the gods, and thus receive a harsher punishment.
metadata.full_path: 6. Thievery > 6.3. Those who steal from a sept can be considered to have stolen from the gods, and thus receive a harsher punishment.

text: Poaching is forbidden. Lords are generally not tolerant towards poachers and punishments for poaching can include being forced to join the Night's Watch, losing a hand, or being forced to row ships.

metadata.section_title: Poaching is forbidden. Lords are generally not tolerant towards poachers and punishments for poaching can include being forced to join the Night's Watch, losing a hand, or being forced to row ships.
metadata.full_path: 7. Poaching > 7.1. Poaching is forbidden. Lords are generally not tolerant towards poachers and punishments for poaching can include being forced to join the Night's Watch, losing a hand, or being forced to row ships.

text: Outlaws are generally sentenced to death by hanging.

metadata.section_title: Outlaws are generally sentenced to death by hanging.
metadata.full_path: 8. Outlawry > 8.1. Outlaws are generally sentenced to death by hanging.

text: Slavery is illegal in the Seven Kingdoms.

metadata.section_title: Slavery is illegal in the Seven Kingdoms.
metadata.full_path: 9. Slavery > 9.1. Slavery is illegal in the Seven Kingdoms.

text: Both the old gods and the Faith of the Seven consider slavery to be an abomination, and as such, there have been no slaves in the Seven Kingdoms for thousands of years

metadata.section_title: Both the old gods and the Faith of the Seven consider slavery to be an abomination, and as such, there have been no slaves in the Seven Kingdoms for thousands of years

text: The punishment for selling people in the Seven Kingdoms is execution

text: An alternative for most punishments is joining the Night's Watch.

metadata.section_title: An alternative for most punishments is joining the Night's Watch.
metadata.full_path: 10. Watch > 10.1. An alternative for most punishments is joining the Night's Watch.

text: Debtors, poachers, thieves, and murderers are among those who might be forced to join the black brothers on the Wall.

text: Men of the Night's Watch are required to swear a vow, by which means their crimes are washed away and all debts are forgiven.

text: A baker who mixes sawdust in his flour, might be fined. If such a fine cannot be paid, he might be whipped instead.
